entries.author: Brigid Delaney
entries.title: Reasons Not to Worry: How to be Stoic in chaotic times

entries.author: Dan Simmons
entries.title: Hyperion Cantos book 2 the fall of Hyperion

entries.author: Martha Wells
entries.title: All Systems Red: The Murderbot Diaries

series_table.author: Douglas Adams
series_table.reviewText: A childhood favorite. Cried with laughter. Re-read so much as a child that my anthology fell apart.
series_table.seriesName: The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy

series_table.author: James S. A. Corey
series_table.reviewText: Not great literature but so entertaining. Like watching a movie. I became caught up with the world and the characters. I enjoyed the "realistic" portrayal of a future where humanities problems haven't been solved but rather expanded in scope. The optimistic end turned these novels from a bleak prediction to one of ultimate hope for humanity.

series_table.author: Robert Jordan
series_table.reviewText: The series I have loved the most. The epic scape, intricate world building and action. I agree with critics who say that the middle volumes are overly long and drag. However it inspired my imagination, brought me to tears and shouts of triumph. I grew to know, love and hate the characters. I have re-read the full series three times.

series_table.author: Liu Cixin
series_table.reviewText: One of my favorite book series. I loved the concept of a deadline to save the earth and how it would impact society over centuries. The interplay between the cultural revolution and the modern day was told brilliantly. Strange and compelling.

series_table.author: Hilary Mantel
series_table.reviewText: Brought the world of the court and times of Henry VIII to life. I loved the characters and the world that HM built. The characters danced in my mind and their voices sang in my head.

series_table.author: Iain Banks
series_table.reviewText: Loved the world that was built and the optimism for the future. One could argue that these novels are techno-humanist in their message. Though they are more adventure stories. "The Player of Games" is by far my favorite novel. Exploring sexual politics, equality and morality. I like the fact that moral equivalence is rejected.

series_table.author: George R. R. Martin
series_table.reviewText: A classic, third favorite fantasy series so far (after Wheel of Time and Malazan Book of the Fallen).
series_table.seriesName: The Song of Ice and Fire

series_table.author: Barbara Kingsolver
series_table.reviewText: A beautiful description of a lost time in Mexico and the life of a young man. Weaving in Mexican and World history and betrayal.

series_table.author: Herman Melville
series_table.reviewText: I read this when I was about 16 on a summer holiday. While I can't remember much of the novel I know I enjoyed it a great deal. I'm sure I will re-read at some point.

series_table.author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
series_table.reviewText: A great take on science fiction and the lost earth genre. The spiders were a great way to explore what it means to be a moral creature and to explore the value of life.

series_table.author: Margaret Atwood
series_table.reviewText: Difficult to read due to its content but fascinating and alarming.

series_table.author: Andrzej Sapkowski
series_table.reviewText: Enjoyable short stories. There is some exploration of themes of love, loss, betrayal and compassion. Not great literature. Good beach/holiday reading.

series_table.author: John Ajvide Lindqvist
series_table.reviewText: Read in my early 20s, loved the dark moodiness of the story. One of the first if not the first horror novel I have read.

series_table.author: Neil Gaiman
series_table.reviewText: A modern fairytale that I enjoyed. The world building and characterisation was engaging. However I have found that Neil Gaiman's characters are very similar in each novel and his writing of female characters is one dimensional.

series_table.author: Frank Herbert
series_table.reviewText: Highly variable. I enjoyed the first three and last two novels but found the writing style overly stylized. There is so much love for Dune that I felt I needed to read it as a Sci-Fi and fantasy fan.
